content: this week I got some more ideas and tips for you on doing full cardstock armies
previously we talked about multi basing and making scenic units for your fantasy
war game but storage has become a big issue for those and I've learned this
the hard way so here's a way to make separate bases and minis for compact
storage while also addressing a nuance that allows you to correctly rank up all
your models plus a few other little tips that I have not explicitly talked about
before start out with dollar store foamboard and draw a grid in this
example I'm going to be making some 25 millimeter bases but the concept is
identical for a 20 millimeter or any sized base for that matter now you want
to score partially through the foamboard but unlike we did in episode 9 don't
score it through the center instead score it a quarter of the way from an
edge crack it the rest of the way and then take a penny or other weight such
as a small washer and hot glue it to the bottom notice that this rigid piece will
keep the two pieces of foam cinched together and this is what provides the
tightness we need to bite the cardstock miniature when you insert it flock these
up as usual with pebbles and sand make sure you apply the white PVA glue
carefully with a brush don't allow it to get into the crack base with burnt umber
dry brush with tan and apply a lighter brown to the side in this case I'm using
bark Brown and here they are after drying I really love this color scheme
and this is how I do all my miniatures now instead of embellishing too much
this kind of mud Brown looks great on a green meadow and icy Tundra a swamp or
pretty much anywhere if you add green flock it kind of breaks the mood on say
a winter battle man so here's another tip to make your ranked up units look
awesome use two or three different poses or images in this case I bought some
evil Knights from mayhem and paper available on drive-thru RPG and it
included eight different poses and these are especially great because they
actually have different backs I picked three of the more common looking poses
and reserve the other five for a different kind of unit later on but then
I took those three and I flipped them horizontally so that they're mirror
images giving me effectively six unique poses to pick from I've gotten a lot of
mileage out of that simple technique look at this unit of Reapers that's
actually eight of the same single figure but half the models have been flipped
and then I attach them in a random non repeating order so you get a nice
chaotic filled out looking unit of models from one image so anyway here's
my 6 different styles and I'm sorting them into piles since my regiment will
have 20 models 2 of these poses are gonna have 4 instances instead of 3 but
that's fine note these were made exactly as described in episode 9 but it is
crucial that you do leave the black tab at the bottom don't exclude it or cut it
off and I just made a small envelope to
store all of them now as you go and insert them in the basis alternate which
way is the front facing in other words the larger side of the base should be on
the quote front side half the time and here's why I have ranked them up and
inserted them into a movement tray and you can see how I alternated every other
one that was made possible because of the offset we cut into the bases even
though the figures themselves might stick out beyond their base footprint
it's okay they don't collide with any of their neighbors because of the offset
now you'll notice that these guys are oriented laterally because they have a
nice front and back image so it's easy to tell which way is front-facing but if
you don't have that or you're just doing our exact technique from episode 9 so
that both sides look identical then this doesn't work because you don't know
which way is front if that's the case simply rotate all the bases in the
movement tray by 90 degrees like you see here and the offset again will still
work although I know in this picture you're seeing we don't have offsets this
is an old picture before I standardized my approach the point is if you look
straight on at the regiment all the cardstock miniatures disappear or if you
don't like that here's one final idea to introduce that nice chaotic filled out
look cut the base slits at random angles see how these two units look fairly
decent each of them is only using a single image identical on both sides of
the model notice also that the elven spearmen have toothpicks painted to look
like Spears very simple but adding one little 3d element to a 2d cardstock
miniature can work absolute miracles for improving the overall look like check
out this undead worm rider separate wing pieces attached at an angle with the
whole thing mounted on a chunk of dark matter
and movement tres easy this is a big rectangle of chipboard with five
millimeter wide foam board walls so if you need say a hundred millimeters in
order to hold five miniatures in a row cut the chipboard to a hundred and
twelve millimeters that gives you five for each wall plus two millimeters to
spare from minor error it won't affect the game meaningfully besides you're not
taking these to an official event or anything this card stock army stuff is
really meant for the kitchen table only I am why lock thank you for joining me
and I'll see you next time
